subject: Properly reconnect subscribing clients when QPID broker restarts
commit_message:
Properly reconnect subscribing clients when QPID broker restarts

When the QPID broker is restarted (or fails over), subscribed clients
will attempt to re-establish their connections.  In the case of fanout
subscriptions, this reconnection functionality is broken. For version
1 topologies, the clients attempt to reconnect twice to the same
exclusive address - which is illegal.  In the case of version 2
topologies, the address parsing is broken and an illegal address is
created on reconnect.  This fix avoids the problem by removing the
special-case reconnect code that manages UUID addresses; it is
unnecessary as the QPID broker will generate unique queue names
automatically when the clients reconnect.

Closes-bug: #1251757
Co-authored-by: Mark McLoughlin <markmc@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I6051fb503663bb8c7c5468db6bcde10f6cf1b318

subject: Expose bulk-operation limits in /info.
commit_message:
Expose bulk-operation limits in /info.

These will allow clients to perform the minimal number of requests
required to accomplish some bulk tasks. For example, a client with
many objects to delete can learn that the cluster's limit on
deletes-per-request is, say, 128, and then batch up their deletes in
groups of 128. Without this, the client has to either discover the
limit out-of-band somehow (and get notified if it changes), or do some
sort of binary search to figure out the limit.

Similar reasoning applies to the containers-per-request value.

The errors-per-request values are included so that clients may size
their requests such that everything is attempted regardless of
failure.

I split the 'bulk' entry into 'bulk_delete' and 'bulk_upload' because,
from a client's standpoint, they're separate operations. It so happens
that Swift implements both in one piece of middleware, but clients
don't care.

Bonus fix: documented a missing config setting for the bulk middleware.

subject: [PRD-2455] Add more checks to check_networks task
commit_message:
[PRD-2455] Add more checks to check_networks task

Following checks are implemented now for Nova-Network:

1) +  VLANs of all networks shouldn't be intersected to each other (all network modes) or Fixed VLAN range (VLAN manager).
2) +  IP address spaces of all networks in cluster shouldn't be intersected to each other (exception: Floating ranges can be in Public CIDR).
3) +  IP address ranges inside Public and Floating networks shouldn't be intersected to each other.
4) +  Public ranges should be in one CIDR which calculated by netmask.
5) +  Public network should have a gateway field and it should belong to Public CIDR but should not be in any Public or Floating range.
6) +- Public and Floating networks are rated as a single network when they assigned to nodes' physical interfaces.
      So they must share one VLAN and must be assigned together to one interface.
7) +  Any physical interface of any node can have one assigned untagged network only (exception: point 6).
8)  - All networks should belong to the allowed IP ranges (network of class A, B or C excluding loopback range).
9) +  VLAN IDs shouldn't be out of range 2, 4094. Untagged network should have VLAN ID == None.
10) - Number of Fixed networks should fit in Fixed CIDR and size of one Fixed network.

Some error messages are refined and unified.

subject: Make certificate subject RFC-4514 compliant
commit_message:
Make certificate subject RFC-4514 compliant

OpenSSL utilizes a proprietary format for DN's (Distinguished Name). A
certificate subject is the most common use of a DN in X509 but they
appear elsewhere as well. The string representation of a DN has been
standarized for well over a decade. RFC-4514 is the current RFC. All
other crypto libraries and tools use RFC-4514 format, OpenSSL is the
exception. OpenStack should follow internet standards and be capable
of interoperating with other compliant implementations.

This patch does the following:

Changes the existing cert subjects in the documentation and config
files to be RFC-4514 compliant.

Introduces a new module dn_conv.py which is capable of converting
between RFC-4514 DN's and OpenSSL format DN's. dn_conv.py has a
matching unit test, test_dn_conv.py.

Performs a check in openssl.BaseCertificateConfigure to see if the
cert subject is in OpenSSL format, if so a deprecation warning is
emitted. If the subject is RFC-4514 compliant it's converted to
OpenSSL format prior to being passed to OpenSSL.

Adds a dependency on python-ldap to perform DN parsing and
construction. Note, python-ldap was already a testing requirement.

DocImpact

Fixes: Bug #1214147

VersionNegotiation - 404 if no version is provided

The version negotiation middleware tries to identify the API version for
a specific url, and then perform routing. It also provides version info
if you attempt to reach "/versions". However, it also returns version
info if you attempt to reach any other endpoint that does not match a
version url.
The version negotiation middleware was modified in order to return all
the available versions of the api only when:

 2- The request path is / or /versions
If the version is not provided and the request path is other than the
two mentioned earlier a 404 HTTP Code is returned.
If a version is provided the middleware strips the version from the URI and
pass the request to the next middleware/app.

subject: Fix Neutron Authentication for Metadata Service
commit_message:
Fix Neutron Authentication for Metadata Service

A recent change to the way Nova creates a Neutron client
51e5f52e4cb60e266ccde71f205c91eb8c97b48b changed the conditions
under which it re-authenticates using the neutron admin credentials
from "if admin" to "if admin or context.is_admin".  However this
meant that any user with admin role in Nova interacted with Neutron
as a different tenant, preventing them from non-admin actions such
as allocating floating IPS.

This was then addressed by 1c1371c78b990447aeaa4377b512f8887e6ff3ce
which only reauthenticated as admin on the explicit use of
"admin=True" parameter to neutonv2.get_client().

However the metadata service does not explicitly create the neutron
client so it has to pass in a context created by
context.get_admin_context() which has is_admin=True but no auth_token.

This change therefore accepts this combination of context values
as a valid reason to re-authenticate as admin, while still allowing
users with the admin role to use their own token.

As a tidy up two tests for getting an admin client are moved from
TestNeutonClient to join the other admin client tests in
TestNeutronClientForAdminScenarios

subject: Fail when image is bigger than the volume
commit_message:
Fail when image is bigger than the volume

When creating a new volume from a qcow2 image stored in glance, we will
be given the physical size of the image instead of the virtual size.
Most drivers will convert that image to raw after downloading for
resizing it to the requested volume size afterwards.

If the virtual size of the image is bigger than the requested one, the
resulting volume might end up being unusable after the resize even
though the creation went good.

This patch will make the volume creation fail if the virtual size of
the image exceeds the one of the requested volume.

subject: Recommend using the stack user to ssh to the seed
commit_message:
Recommend using the stack user to ssh to the seed

We currently recommend using root to ssh to the seed, but using the
stack user works just fine too since the stackuser element will copy
your SSH key if the local-config element is enabled.

I think it's better to recommend people use the stack user because at
least that same user will work on the undercloud and overcloud, even
if it requires a password in those cases.

Basically, I'm finding myself randomly trying root, stack and heat-admin
and struggling to remember which user is appropriate for each node.
